node.title: How to Watch Nathan Chen Chase Gold in Men’s Figure Skating
node.alt: Nathan Chen during his short program on Tuesday in Beijing.
node.description: If Chen can maintain his lead in the free skate, he’ll win an Olympic gold medal. His rival, Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, is looking for a comeback.
node.content: ["After a world-record performance in the men\u2019s short program, the American Nathan Chen will attempt to maintain his lead and capture his first Olympic gold medal in figure skating\u2019s individual competition, while his rival, Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, has his eyes set on a comeback and a piece of history by landing the first quadruple axel in competition.", "Chen\u2019s short program score, 113.97, has him comfortably ahead of the field heading into the free skate on Thursday morning in Beijing (Wednesday night in the United States). The medal winners are determined by adding scores together for the short program and the free skate, also known as the long program.", "Here\u2019s how to watch.", "The free skate competition will start at 8:30 p.m. Eastern on Wednesday, or 9:30 a.m. on Thursday in Beijing.", "NBC will carry the event live on television and on Peacock, its streaming service.", "The 24 skaters will perform in order of their short program score, lowest to highest, so Chen will be last to skate. That will probably happen after midnight on the East Coast.", "Chen has dominated the sport since his disappointing performance in 2018, when a miserable short program left him far short of the medal stand. Hanyu won Olympic gold in 2014 and 2018, and was among the top medal contenders heading into Monday\u2019s short program.", "But Hanyu fell during his routine on Monday, finishing in a disappointing eighth place, nearly 19 points behind Chen. Still, his performance in the free skate is one of the most highly anticipated of the Olympics as he\u2019s expected to try a quadruple axel, a feat never landed in competition.", "Other medal contenders include a pair of Japanese skaters, Yuma Kagiyama and Shoma Uno, who placed second and third in the short program. Jason Brown, an American fan favorite, is not far behind in sixth place."]
